title: 105_hr4182
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE. The Congress finds that the Brown v. Board of Education decision was significant, the Little Rock Nine integration was a key example, Central High School is historically important. The Congress recognizes Little Rock Central High School as a national historic landmark for its role in the civil rights movement and desegregation of public schools in the South. The purpose of the Act is to preserve and interpret the school's significance for present and future generations. Establishment of Central High School National Historic Site. The Little Rock Central High School national historic site is established as a unit of the National Park System in Arkansas. The Secretary of the Interior will administer the site in accordance with relevant laws. Cooperative agreements can be made with public and private agencies. The Act of August 25, 1916 and August 21, 1935 allows the Little Rock School District to administer Little Rock Central High School. The Secretary can enter into cooperative agreements with various agencies and institutions for the site's purposes. A general management plan must be prepared within 2 years, and educational use will involve consultation with the school district. The Secretary is required to prepare a general management plan for the historic site within 2 years. They must consult with the Little Rock School District to ensure that the administration of the site does not interfere with the school's educational use. The Secretary is authorized to acquire lands within the site with consent from the owner, and lands owned by the State of Arkansas or a political subdivision may only be acquired by donation or exchange. "DESEGREGATION IN PUBLIC EDUCATION THEME STUDY." The Secretary is required to prepare a national historic landmark theme study on the history of desegregation in public education within 2 years. The study will identify sites that illustrate key events in the movement for racial desegregation in education and propose new national historic landmarks. Additionally, the study will explore opportunities for education and research by establishing linkages between identified sites and existing units of the National Park System. The theme study will establish linkages between sites related to desegregation in public education and recommend cooperative arrangements with various entities to preserve and interpret key historical sites. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with educational institutions and civil rights organizations to ensure scholarly standards are met. The theme study will be prepared as part of the general management plan. The theme study for the Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site will be prepared in coordination with the general management plan. Public history and civil rights organizations will be involved to ensure scholarly standards are met. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums may be appropriated as necessary for this Act.
